0.35: And my proud head shall strike upon the sky!

3.0: The touch of Zephyr and of Spring has loosen'd Winter's thrall;
3.1: The well-dried keels are wheel'd again to sea:
3.2: The ploughman cares not for his fire, nor cattle for their stall,
3.3: And frost no more is whitening all the lea.
3.4: Now Cytherea leads the dance, the bright moon overhead;
3.5: The Graces and the Nymphs, together knit,
3.6: With rhythmic feet the meadow beat, while Vulcan , fiery red,
3.7: Heats the Cyclopian forge in Aetna 's pit.
3.8: 'Tis now the time to wreathe the brow with branch of myrtle green,
3.9: Or flowers, just opening to the vernal breeze;
3.10: Now Faunus claims his sacrifice among the shady treen,
3.11: Lambkin or kidling, which soe'er he please.
3.12: Pale Death, impartial, walks his round: he knocks at cottage-gate
3.13: And palace-portal. Sestius, child of bliss!
3.14: How should a mortal's hopes be long, when short his being's date?
3.15: Lo here! the fabulous ghosts, the dark abyss,
3.16: The void of the Plutonian hall, where soon as e'er you go,
3.17: No more for you shall leap the auspicious die
3.18: To seat you on the throne of wine; no more your breast shall glow
3.19: For Lycidas, the star of every eye.

6.0: Let others Rhodes or Mytilene sing,
6.1: Or Ephesus , or Corinth , set between
6.2: Two seas, or Thebes , or Delphi , for its king
6.3: Each famous, or Thessalian Tempe green;
6.4: There are who make chaste Pallas' virgin tower
6.5: The daily burden of unending song,
6.6: And search for wreaths the olive's rifled bower:
6.7: The praise of Juno sounds from many a tongue,
6.8: Telling of Argos ' steeds, Mycenae 's gold.
6.9: For me stern Sparta forges no such spell,
6.10: No, nor Larissa's plain of richest mould,
6.11: As bright Albunea echoing from her cell.
6.12: O headlong Anio! O Tiburnian groves,
6.13: And orchards saturate with shifting streams!
6.14: Look how the clear fresh south from heaven removes
6.15: The tempest, nor with rain perpetual teems!
6.16: You too be wise, my Plancus: life's worst cloud
6.17: Will melt in air, by mellow wine allay'd,
6.18: Dwell you in camps, with glittering banners proud,
6.19: Or 'neath your Tibur 's canopy of shade.
6.20: When Teucer fled before his father's frown
6.21: From Salamis , they say his temples deep
6.22: He dipp'd in wine, then wreath'd with poplar crown,
6.23: And bade his comrades lay their grief to sleep:
6.24: “Where Fortune bears us, than my sire more kind,
6.25: There let us go, my own, my gallant crew.
6.26: 'Tis Teucer leads, 'tis Teucer breathes the wind;
6.27: No more despair; Apollo's word is true.
6.29: Shall yet arise. Hearts, that have borne with me
6.30: Worse buffets! drown today in wine your care;
6.31: To-morrow we recross the wide, wide sea!”

10.0: Ask not ('tis forbidden knowledge), what our destined term of years,
10.1: Mine and yours; nor scan the tables of your Babylonish seers.

10.3: Whether Jove has many winters yet to give, or this our last;
10.4: This , that makes the Tyrrhene billows spend their strength against the shore.
10.5: Strain your wine and prove your wisdom; life is short; should hope be more?
10.6: In the moment of our talking, envious time has ebb'd away.
10.7: Seize the present; trust tomorrow e'en as little as you may.

17.0: Varus, are your trees in planting? put in none before the vine,
17.1: In the rich domain of Tibur , by the walls of Catilus;
17.2: There's a power above that hampers all that sober brains design,
17.3: And the troubles man is heir to thus are quell'd, and only thus.
17.4: Who can talk of want or warfare when the wine is in his head,
17.5: Not of thee, good father Bacchus, and of Venus fair and bright?
17.6: But should any dream of licence, there's a lesson may be read,
17.7: How 'twas wine that drove the Centaurs with the Lapithae to fight.
17.8: And the Thracians too may warn us; truth and falsehood, good and ill,
17.9: How they mix them, when the wine-god's hand is heavy on them laid!
17.10: Never, never, gracious Bacchus, may I move thee 'gainst thy will,
17.11: Or uncover what is hidden in the verdure of thy shade!
17.12: Silence thou thy savage cymbals, and the Berecyntine horn;
17.13: In their train Self-love still follows, dully, desperately blind,
17.14: And Vain-glory, towering upwards in its emptyheaded scorn,
17.15: And the Faith that keeps no secrets, with a window in its mind.
